phrases.original: Every invite that you send promotes a specific church event. You'll need some events in order to send your invites. You can get events through either (or both) of the following two methods:

phrases.original: There are two ways to get events:
phrases.translated: There are two ways to get events:

phrases.original: When you follow another user, you can use any of their events in your own invites. This has some powerful advantages:
phrases.translated: When you follow another user, you can use any of their events in your own invites. This has some powerful advantages:

phrases.original: Accuracy. You won't have to keep any of the event details up-to-date. The user that you follow will be responsible for that.
phrases.translated: Accuracy. You won't have to keep any of the event details up-to-date. The user that you follow will be responsible for that.

phrases.original: Convenience. It takes time to write a motivational event description, and to assemble all of the other relevant information (like meeting times, dates, locations, contact info and virtual streaming connection info, which are always subject to change). You can leave these details to someone else.
phrases.translated: Convenience. It takes time to write a motivational event description, and to assemble all of the other relevant information (like meeting times, dates, locations, contact info and virtual streaming connection info, which are always subject to change). You can leave these details to someone else.

phrases.original: Consistency. When the person you follow is one of your ministry leaders (such as your evangelist or Bible Talk leader), following and sharing their events can result in an outreach message that is consistent for everyone. This could be effective in creating a sort of 'brand identity' for the group.

phrases.original: You should add an event in these scenarios:
phrases.translated: You should add an event in these scenarios:

phrases.original: To personalize it. Add an event when you want to describe it in your own personal writing style, emphasizing whatever personally resonates with you. If you have a highly distinct personality (and if it closely matches your writing style), a personalized invite might seem more authentic to its recipients.

phrases.original: To lead your group. Add an event when you intend for the people who follow you to use it in their invites. If you are a Bible Talk Leader (or higher), then this is definitely the right option.
